titleStmt.title: Event-triggered Decentralized Tracking Control of Modular Reconfigurable Robots Through Adaptive Dynamic Programming

affiliation.orgName: State Key Laboratory of Management and Control for Complex Systems

analytic.title: Event-triggered Decentralized Tracking Control of Modular Reconfigurable Robots Through Adaptive Dynamic Programming

biblStruct.note: This article has been accepted for publication in a future issue of this journal, but has not been fully edited. Content may change prior to final publication. Citation information: DOI 10.1109/TIE.2019.2914571, IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This paper develops an event-triggered decentralized tracking control (DTC) approach for modular reconfigurable robots (MRRs) by using adaptive dynamic programming. By establishing a decentralized neural network (NN) observer, which uses local input-output data and desired states of coupling subsystems, the local dynamics of MRR subsystem can be obtained. In order to obtain the DTC, the tracking error subsystem is augmented by the exosystem with the desired trajectory. Based on the eventtriggered mechanism and a modified local cost function, the DTC is derived by solving the local Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman equation via a local critic NN with asymptotically stable structure. The stability of the entire closed-loop MRR system is analyzed by Lyapunov's direct method. The simulation of a two-degree of freedom MRR system ensures that the developed event-triggered DTC scheme is effective.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION AND MOTIVATION
div.p: M ODULAR reconfigurable robots (MRRs) [1] that con- sist of many standard joint and link modules can fulfill different tasks by reconfiguring their shapes by adding or removing modules (such as MRR shown in Fig. 1). They are thus always considered as a set of subsystems interconnected by coupling torques. Since they are easily assembled, portable, robust and with low cost, they have wide implementation potentials in many scenes that human cannot involve directly, such as smart manufacturing [2], deep space exploring [3], and high risk environments [4]. To undertake these tasks, the computational burden, the communication bandwidth and the energy saving are the key issues to be concerned besides the control performance in control applications.

Manuscript received August 28, 2018; revised February 7, 2019; accepted April 10, 2019. This work was supported in part by the National Natural Science Foundation of China under Grants 61603387, 61773075, 61533017 and U1501251, and in part by the Early Career Development Award of SKLMCCS under Grant 20180201.

Bo Zhao is with the School of Systems Science, Beijing Normal University, Beijing 100875, China, and also with the State Key Laboratory of Management and Control for Complex Systems, Institute of Automation, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100190, China. email: zhaobo@bnu.edu.cn.

Derong Liu is with the School of Automation, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou 510006, China. Corresponding author of this paper, e-mail: derong@gdut.edu.cn. In the literature of MRR control methods, they can be categorized into three strategies, i.e., centralized control [5]- [7], distributed control [8]- [10] and decentralized control [11]- [13]. The centralized control is designed by employing the information of all subsystems, which leads to increasing difficulties of analysis and synthesis with the growing dimension of large-scale systems. The distributed control strategy uses the information of local and neighboring subsystems to solve the increasing dimensional difficulties in centralized control strategy. In contrast to distributed control, the decentralized control strategy, which requires less communication exchange since it uses only the local subsystem information and without communicating with its neighbors, provides a simpler control architecture, and it thus is more applicable to MRRs which consist of standard modules and changeable configurations. Based on the decentralized control strategy, Li et al. [11] proposed a backstepping based decentralized robust control scheme for MRRs without requiring the exact dynamic knowledge. Zhu et al. [12] developed a stable decentralized adaptive fuzzy sliding mode control scheme with compensation for MRRs with unknown dynamics. Zhao et al. [13] established a set of observers to achieve active fault tolerant control based on local joint information for MRRs with uncertainties. In our recent work [14], a near-optimal decentralized tracking control (DTC) is proposed by using adaptive dynamic programming (ADP) technique in the timetriggered environment. We can know from the above works that the decentralized control schemes, which employs the local joint module information only, is more suitable to be applied to different MRRs with a plenty of joint modules and changeable configurations due to the modularization property of MRRs. On the other hand, taking [7] as a practical example, the master-slave control was supported by an FPGA and a high speed communication system modified from Spacewire (IEEE1355) to transfer a limited amount of data between the master and slave nodes. It implies that the resource of the field bus bandwidth, the communication and the energy is extremely valuable and should be saved. Generally speaking, the timetriggered control scheme for MRRs has too much unexpected computation, communication and energy to be saved for a longer working time in the aforementioned environments. To the best of our knowledge, event-triggered control for MRRs is yet to be considered.

As we all know, optimal control problems for linear systems can be solved by Riccati equations. While, for nonlinear systems, this challenging and difficult task can be addressed by dynamic programming (DP) algorithm assisted by Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman (HJB) equation. However, it always results in difficulty due to the well known "curse of dimensionality". To avoid this issue, the so-called ADP [15], [16], which is assisted by the approximators, such as neural networks (NNs), has been paid considerable attention as a powerful technique to handle the control problems of nonlinear systems with continuous-time [17], discrete-time [18], uncertainties and external disturbances [19], actuator failure [20], input constraints [21], etc. As well, we have made great efforts on addressing decentralized control problems by using ADP recently [14], [22], [23]. It is well known that the intermittent communication [24]- [27] related to a prior time can guarantee the stability and the energy conservation of the systems. By employing it, the event-triggered control is effective to address energy, computation and communication constraints. At the same time, it is close to the way of human behaves naturally [28]. Under the framework of event-triggered mechanism, the control action is updated solely when certain conditions are violated to ensure both the stability and control performance of the plants. In recent years, the event-triggered ADP-based control is considered as a novel strategy to address the control problems for nonlinear systems. Vamvoudakis et al. [29] proposed a model-free event-triggered optimal control scheme for continuous-time linear systems by employing a Qlearning framework based critic NN. Dong et al. [30] presented an event-triggered heuristic dynamic programming-based adaptive control for unknown nonlinear discrete-time systems through an actor-critic architecture. Narayanan et al. [31] established an ADP-based online exploration event-triggered state feedback distributed control scheme for affine nonlinear interconnected systems. Moreover, event-triggered ADP-based control schemes were applied to the heating, ventilation and air conditioning systems [32] and power systems [33]. From the above literature, we acknowledge that the control action is updated only when an event is triggered. It implies that the computation, communication and energy cost are all reduced.

MRRs have the potential to be implemented to fulfill the tasks that human beings cannot involve directly in those aforementioned environments, and the resource in computation, communication and energy should be utilized reasonably and effectively. Motivated from these requirements and our previous work [14] on time-triggered DTC, this paper addresses the event-triggered DTC problems for MRRs based on ADP. In contrast to the existing methods, the main novelties and superiorities of the developed scheme can be summarized as follows.

1) The developed method extends the ADP-based eventtriggered control strategy to address the DTC problems for MRRs. It makes the actual trajectory of each joint module follows its desired one, which not only ensures the closedloop system of MRR to be asymptotically stable, but also leads to a decentralized optimal control structure. 2) This scheme reduces the computational burden, and saves the communication and energy cost, which are significant to MRRs that are implemented in the environments human beings cannot involve directly. 3) By employing the nested update laws, the modified local cost function is approximated by the local critic NN with an asymptotically stable structure, rather than guaranteing it to be ultimately uniformly bounded (UUB) in the existing methods.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In Section II, the control problem of MRRs is formulated, and the subsystem dynamic model is developed. In Section III, a decentralized NN observer and local critic NN are established, and the event-triggered DTC scheme is designed. Then, the system stability and Zeno behavior exclusion are analyzed in detail. In Section IV, the simulation on a 2-DOF MRR is provided to illustrate the effectiveness of the developed event-triggered DTC scheme. In Section V, the conclusion is drawn.

Notations: R presents the set of all real numbers, R m and R m×n denote the Euclidean space of all real m-vectors and the space of all m × n real matrices, respectively. T is the symbol of transposition. I n is the identity matrix with n×n dimensions. When
div.formula: ζ = [ζ 1 , . . . , ζ n ] ∈ R n , ∥ζ∥ = √ ∑ n i=1 |ζ i | 2 is the Euclidean norm of ζ. When E ∈ R m×n , ∥E∥ is the Frobenius-norm of E.
div.p: N is the set of all nonnegative integers. Ω is a compect subset of R n . diag(•) ∈ R n×n represents a diagonal matrix with n × n dimensions. λ max (•) and λ min (•) calculate the maximal and minimal eigenvalues of a matrix, respectively.

div.head: II. PROBLEM FORMULATION
div.p: Consider the n-DOF MRR system, whose dynamics are M (q)q + C(q, q) q + G(q) = u, (1) where q ∈ R n is the vector of joint displacements, M (q) ∈ R n×n is the inertia matrix, C(q, q) ∈ R n×n is the Coriolis and centripetal force, G(q) ∈ R n is the gravity term, and u ∈ R n is the applied joint torque.

To develop the event-triggered DTC scheme for MRRs with n-DOF, each standard joint module is regarded as a subsystem interconnected by coupling torque of the entire MRR system. By separating independent local variables (q i , qi , qi ) from interconnections among coupling subsystems, the subsystem dynamics can be reformulated in joint space as where Z i (q, q, q) is the coupling torque given as
div.formula: M i (q i )q i + C i (q i , qi ) qi + G i (q i ) + Z i (q, q, q) = u i , (
Z i (q, q, q) =    n ∑ k=1,k̸ =i M ik (q)q k + [M ii (q) -M i (q i )]q i    +    n ∑ k=1,k̸ =i C ik (q, q) qk + [C ii (q, q) -C i (q i , qi )] qi    + [ Ḡi (q) -G i (q i ) ] ,
div.p: where q i , qi , qi , G i (q) and ūi are the ith element of vectors q, q, q, G(q) and u, M ik (q) and C ik (q, q) are the ikth element of matrices M (q) and C(q, q), respectively.
Let
div.formula: x i = [x i1 , x i2 ] T = [q i , qi ] T ∈ R 2 .
div.p: (2) can be expressed
div.formula: as { ẋi1 = x i2 , ẋi2 = fi (x i ) + ḡi (x i )u i (x i ) + hi (x),(3)
div.p: where x i is the state of the ith subsystem, and
div.formula: fi (x i ) = M -1 i (q i ) [-C i (q i , qi ) qi -G i (q i )] , ḡi (x i ) = M -1 i (q i ), hi (x) = -M -1 i (q i )Z i (q, q, q),
div.p: where hi (x) is the interconnection term, x = [x 1 , . . . , x n ] T is the state vector of the entire MRR.

In order to make full use of desired states of coupling subsystems and increase the modeling accuracy, we substitute the desired states of the coupling subsystems into the interconnection term. We rewrite the interconnection term as
div.formula: hi (x) = hi (x i , x kd ) + ∆ hi (x, x kd ),(4)
div.p: where x kd denotes the desired states of the kth coupled subsystems, hi (x i , x kd ) is a function which extracts the state information of the ith subsystem and the desired state information of the kth subsystems from hi (x), ∆ hi (x, x kd ) = hi (x) -hi (x i , x kd ) denotes the substitution error. Thus, (
div.formula: { ẋi1 = x i2 , ẋi2 = fi (x i , x kd ) + ḡi (x i )u i (x i ) + ∆ hi (x, x kd ).3) becomes
div.p: Then, ( 5) can be rewritten as
div.formula: ẋi = f i (x i , x kd ) + g i (x i )u i (t) + ∆h i (x, x kd ),(6)
div.p: where
div.formula: f i (x i , x kd ) = [ x i2 , fi (x i , x kd ) ] T , fi (x i , x kd ) = fi (x i )+ hi (x i , x kd ), g i (x i ) = [0, ḡi (x i )]
div.p: T , and
div.formula: ∆h i (x, x kd ) = [ 0, ∆ hi (x, x kd ) ] T .
div.p: Assumption 1: The nonlinear functions f i (x i , x kd ), g i (x i ) and ∆h i (x, x kd ) are Lipschitz and continuous in their arguments with f i (0) = 0, and the subsystem ( 6) is controllable.
Assumption 2: The desired trajectory x id is twice differentiable and the vector
div.formula: X id = [x id , ẋid , ẍid ]
div.p: T is bounded as
div.formula: ∥X id ∥ ≤ q iM , (7
div.p: where q iM is a known positive constant.

Since f i (x i , x kd ) and g i (x i ) are Lipschitz continuous according to Assumption 1, fi (x i , x kd ) is still Lipschitz continuous on a set Ω i ∈ R 2 . Since the interconnection term ∆h i (x, x kd ) satisfies the Lipschitz condition, which implies
div.formula: ∥∆h i (x, x kd )∥ ≤ n ∑ j=1 d ik E k , (8
div.p: where E k = ∥x k -x kd ∥, and d ik ≥ 0 is an unknown Lipschitz constant.
To achieve the desired output trajectory, we can use the exosystem for the ith subsystem as
div.formula: ẋid = f id (x id ),(9)
div.p: where f id (x id ) is a Lipschitz continuous function.
For the ith subsystem, the tracking error is defined as e i = x i -x id . The tracking error dynamics thus can be defined as
div.formula: ėi = f i (x i , x kd ) + g i (x i )u i + ∆h i (x, x kd ) -f id (x id ). (10)
div.p: Inspired by [34]- [36], we define the augmented subsystem states as
div.formula: x ia = [e i , x id ]
div.p: T ∈ R 2n , and the augmented subsystem becomes
div.formula: ẋia = f ia (x ia ) + g ia (x i )u i (t) + ∆h ia (x a ),(11)
div.p: where
div.formula: f ia (x ia ) = [f i (e i + x id ) -f id (x id ), f id (x id )] T , g ia (x ia ) = [g i (e i + x id ), 0] T , ∆h ia (x a ) = [∆h i (x, x kd ), 0] T ,
div.p: and
div.formula: x a = [x, x kd ] T .
div.p: To transform the time-varying optimal control problem into a time-invariant optimal control problem, similar to [34], the nominal augmented subsystem of MRR can be described as
div.formula: ẋia = f ia (x ia ) + g ia (x i )u i (t). (12
div.p: Define the local optimal cost function as
div.formula: V * i (x ia (t), u * i ) = ∫ ∞ t ( ηi ∥∇V * i (x ia )∥ E i + x T ia (τ )Q ia x ia (τ ) +u * T i (τ )R i u * i (τ ) ) dτ, (13
div.p: where ηi is the estimation of the later defined positive constant
div.formula: η i , ∇V i (x ia ) = ∂V i (x ia )/∂x ia is the partial derivative of V i (x ia ) with respect to the subsystem state x ia , Q ia = [ Q i 0 n×n 0 n×n 0 n×n ] ∈ R 2n , R i ∈ R n and Q i ∈ R n are positive
div.p: definite matrices, and 0 n×n is a square matrix of zeros. If ( 13) is continuously differentiable, then its infinitesimal version is the so-called local Lyapunov equation
div.formula: ∇V * i (x ia ) ẋia + ηi ∥∇V * i (x ia )∥ E i + x T ia Q ia x ia + u * T i R i u * i = 0.(14)
div.p: Thus, the Hamiltonian of the optimal problem is defined as
div.formula: H i (x ia ,∇V * i , u * i ) = ∇V * i (x ia ) ẋia + x T ia Q ia x ia + ηi ∥∇V * i (x ia )∥ E i + u * T i R i u * i . (15
div.p: The local optimal cost function V * i (x ia ) is derived by solving the local HJB equation with V * i (0) = 0. Noticing that ( 16) is famous as the classical time-triggered local HJB equation. Thus, the optimal control policy is always given in a time-triggered manner, which suffers from the heavy computational burden, wasting of communication and energy resources between the actuators and the plants. In order to solve the above concerns, it is desirable to design the DTC with sampled state obtained at the triggering time-instant, i.e., the event-triggered control mechanism. It means that the DTC is updated only when the triggering condition is violated. Define a monotonically increasing sequence of triggering timeinstants {t j } ∞ j=0 , where t j is the jth consecutive sampling instant which satisfies
div.formula: min u * i H i (x ia , ∇V * i , u * i ) = 0(
0 ≤ t 0 < t 1 < • • • < t j < • • • and lim j→∞ t j = ∞.
div.p: The output of the sampled-data component is a sequence of the sampled states x iaj (t j ) for all t ∈ [t j , t j+1 ) with j ∈ N. The DTC becomes a continuous-time input signal by the sampled-state mapping with a zero-order hold.

In order to decide whether the event is triggered or not, the so-called event-triggering error function, i.e., the gap function between the current state x ia (t) and the sampled state x iaj (t j ) can be defined as
div.formula: e iaj (t) = x ia -x iaj , ∀t ∈ [t j , t j+1 ), j ∈ N,(17)
div.p: where
div.formula: x iaj = { x ia (t j ), ∀t ∈ [t j , t j+1 ),
div.p: x iaj (t), t = t j+1 . In the event-triggered control mechanism, the triggering condition is provided in terms of the event-triggered error and a state-dependent threshold. When the event is triggered, the subsystem state is sampled to reset the event-triggered error e iaj (t) to zero, and the DTC is updated as
div.formula: u i (x ia (t j )) = u i (x iaj ) during the time interval [t j , t j+1 ), j ∈ N.
div.p: This paper is interested in finding an ADP-based eventtriggered DTC policy u i (x iaj ) to minimize the local cost function such that the actual state of each MRR subsystem follows its desired trajectory. Furthermore, the set of DTC policies u 1 (x 1aj ), u 2 (x 2aj ), . . . , u n (x naj ) ensures the closedloop system of entire MRR to be stable. Meanwhile, the avoidance of unexpected Zeno behavior is guaranteed.

div.head: A. Event-triggered DTC scheme
div.p: In the time-triggered case, the optimal DTC is expressed as
div.formula: u * i (x ia ) = - 1 2 R -1 i g T ia (x ia )∇V * i (x ia ).(18)
div.p: Thus, we have
div.formula: ∇V * T i g ia (x ia ) = -2u * T i R i . (19
div.p: By introducing the event-triggered mechanism, for ∀t ∈ [t j , t j+1 ), the optimal DTC (18) becomes
div.formula: u * i (x iaj ) = - 1 2 R -1 i g T ia (x iaj )∇V * i (x iaj ).(20)
div.p: Since the zero-order hold is introduced, we can observe that ( 20) is a continuous input signal when the event is not triggered, and u * i (x iaj ) is a discretized value of ( 18) at the triggering time-instant t j .
Assumption 3: The optimal DTC u * i is Lipschitz continuous, i.e., for each state pair (x ia , x iaj ), there exists a positive constant k i such that
div.formula: ∥u * i (x ia ) -u * i (x iaj )∥ ≤ k i ∥x ia -x iaj ∥ = k i ∥e iaj ∥ . (21) Remark 1:
div.p: In the event-triggered optimal DTC scheme (20), the subsystem state x ia is substituted by x iaj in the gap function (17), which determines the triggering time-instant t j to reset the subsystem state as e iaj = 0, i.e., x ia (t j ) = x iaj , and update the DTC policy as u i (x ia (t j )) = u i (x iaj ) during the time interval [t j , t j+1 ), j ∈ N. Similarly, the next triggering time t j+1 can be determined by the next reset as x ia(j+1) with ( 17) when the triggering condition holds.

div.head: B. Decentralized NN observer based MRR subsystem identification
div.p: Since the shape and DOF of MRR will be changed according to different tasks, it thus is unreasonable to establish the system model each time. In this part, the local input-output data and the desired states of the coupling subsystems are utilized to obtain local input gain matrix by constructing a decentralized NN observer.
From the expression of ( 20), we know that the eventtriggered DTC can be obtained by the local input gain matrix g ia . For the ith subsystem of MRR (5), letting
div.formula: F i (x i , x kd , u i ) = fi (x i , x kd ) + ḡi (x i )u i (x i ), the radial basis function (RBF) NN is employed to approximate the unknown dynamics F i (x i , x kd , u i ) as F i (x i , x kd , u i ) = W * T iF σ iF (x i , x kd , u i ) + ε iF , (22
div.p: where W iF ∈ R l iF is the ideal weight vector, σ iF (x i , x kd , u i ) ∈ R liF is the radial basis function, l iF is the number of neurons in the hidden layer, ε iF is the approximation error, which is assumed to be norm-bounded as
div.formula: ∥ε iF ∥ ≤ ε iF M with ε iF M a positive constant.
div.p: Define the observation error vector as
div.formula: e io = [e i1o , e i2o ] T = [x i1 -xi1 , x i2 -xi2 ]
div.p: T . According to the subsystem dynamics (5), the decentralized NN observer is established as
div.formula: { ẋi1 = xi2 + l i1o e i1o , ẋi2 = Fi (x i , x kd , u i ) + l i2o e i2o , (23
where xi = [x i1 , xi2 ]
div.p: T is the observation of subsystem state
div.formula: x i , l io = diag [l i1o , l i2o ]
div.p: is the observation gain matrix with all positive elements, Fi (x i , x kd , u i ) = Ŵ T iF σiF (x i , x kd , u i ) is the observation of nonlinear dynamics F i (x i , x kd , u i ), where ŴiF and σiF (x i , x kd , u i ) are the estimations of W iF and σ iF (x i , x kd , u i ), respectively.

Therefore, the local input gain matrix can be derived from the partial gradient of Fi (x i , x kd , u i ) with respect to the local control input u i , i.e., ĝia (x ia ) = ∂ Fi(xi,xkd,ui) ∂ui . Theorem 1: Considering the ith subsystem dynamics of MRR (5), the local input-output data and desired states of coupling subsystems based decentralized NN observer (23) guarantees the local observation error e io to be ultimately uniformly bounded (UUB) with the updating law
div.formula: ẆiF = Γ iF e i2o σiF (x i , x kd , u i ),(24)
div.p: where Γ iF is a positive constant.
Proof: Define the weight estimation error as WiF = W iF -ŴiF . Select a Lyapunov function candidate as
div.formula: L i1 = 1 2 e T io e io + 1 2 W T iF Γ -1 iF WiF . (25
div.p: Its time derivative is
div.formula: Li1 = e i1o ėi1o + e i2o ėi2o -W T iF Γ -1 iF ẆiF (26) = e i1o e i2o -l i1o e 2 i1o -l i2o e 2 i2o + e i2o W T iF σiF + e i2o δ iF -W T iF Γ -1 iF ẆiF , (27
div.p: where
div.formula: δ iF = W T iF σiF + ε iF . Assume that ∥δ iF ∥ ≤ δ iF M with δ iF M a positive constant.
div.p: Substituting ( 24) into (26), it becomes
div.formula: Li1 ≤ e i1o e i2o -l i1o e 2 i1o -l i2o e 2 i2o + ∥e i2o ∥ δ iF M ≤ - (( l i2o -1 2 ) ∥e i2o ∥ -δ iF M ) ∥e i2o ∥ - ( l i1o -1 2 ) e 2 i1o .(28)
div.p: Hence, Li1 ≤ 0 as long as e i2o lies outside the compact set
div.formula: Ω ei2o = { e i2o : ∥e i2o ∥ ≤ δ iF M l i2o -1 2 } ,
div.p: when l i1o ≥ 1 2 and l i2o > 1 2 . Therefore, according to Lyapunov's direct method, the observation error e io can be guaranteed to be UUB. This completes the proof.

Remark 2: The basis function σ iF in the developed decentralized NN observer is determined by using "trial and error" for several times until the approximation error satisfies a given threshold. During the training process, we can observe that a higher convergence rate of the observation error dynamics can be obtained with a large number of variables in σ iF , but the computational burden is heavier. To tradeoff them, σ iF is chosen offline. Noticing that the variables in function σ iF depends on the local input-output data and desired states of the coupling subsystems, thus they should be provided to each observer at the beginning. Thus, no matter the reference trajectory is time-invariant or time-varying, the developed decentralized NN observer (23) is valid.

div.head: C. Local critic neural network
div.p: Since the universal approximation ability, the local optimal cost function ( 13) is constructed by a single hidden layer based NN on a compact set Ω i , i.e., the local critic NN, as
div.formula: V * i (x ia ) = W * T ic σ ic (x ia ) + ε ic (x ia ),(29)
div.p: where W * ic ∈ R lic is the ideal weight vector, σ ic (x ia ) ∈ R lic is the activation function, l ic is the number of neurons in the hidden layer, and ε ic (x ia ) ∈ R is the reconstruction error.
The partial gradient of (29) with respect to x ia is
div.formula: ∇V * i (x ia ) = ∇σ T ic (x ia )W * ic + ∇ε ic (x ia ).(30)
div.p: In order to approximate the unknown ideal weight vector W * ic , the local critic NN can be approximated as
div.formula: Vi (x ia ) = Ŵ T ic σ ic (x ia ),(31)
div.p: where Ŵic ∈ R lic is the approximate weight vector, and we have the gradient vector as
div.formula: ∇ Vi (x ia ) = ∇σ T ic (x ia ) Ŵic . (32
div.p: In the event-triggered case, ( 15) is approximated as
div.formula: Ĥi ( x iaj ,∇ Vi (x iaj ), ûi (x iaj ) ) = ∇ Vi (x iaj ) ẋiaj (t) + ηi ∇ Vi (x iaj ) E i + x T iaj Q ia x iaj + ûT i (x iaj )R i ûi (x iaj ) = e ic , (33
div.p: where ηi is updated as
div.formula: ηi = Γ iη ∇ Vi (x iaj ) E i , (34
div.p: and Γ iη is a positive constant. Defining the weight error vector as Wic = W * ic -Ŵic , and comparing (33) with the optimal local Hamiltonian (15), we have
div.formula: H i ( x ia ,∇V * i (x ia ), u * i (x ia ) ) -Ĥi ( x iaj , ∇ Vi (x iaj ), ûi (x iaj ) ) = ∇V * i (x ia ) ẋia (t) + ηi ∥∇V * i (x ia )∥ E i + x T ia Q ia x ia + u * T i (x ia )R i u * i (x ia ) -∇ Vi (x iaj ) ẋiaj (t) -ηi ∇ Vi (x iaj ) E i -x T iaj Q ia x iaj -ûT i (x iaj )R i ûi (x iaj ) = W T ic ∇σ ic (x iaj ) ẋiaj + δ i ,(35)
div.p: where
div.formula: δ i = δ i1 + δ i2 + δ i3 with δ i1 = ( W T ic ( ∇σ ic (x ia ) -∇σ ic (x iaj ) ) + ε ic ) ẋia (t) + W T ic ∇σ ic (x iaj ) ėiaj + Ŵ T ic ∇σ ic (x ia ) ėiaj (t), δ i2 = ηi ( ∥∇V * i (x ia )∥ -∇ Vi (x iaj ) ) E i , δ i3 = e T iaj Q ia (x ia + x iaj ) + ( u * i (x ia ) + ûi (x iaj ) ) T R i ( u * i (x ia ) -ûi (x iaj )
div.p: ) . Assumption 4: δ i is norm-bounded, i.e., ∥δ i ∥ ≤ δ icM , where δ icM is a positive constant.
Noticing the fact that H i (x ia , ∇V * i (x ia ), u * i (x ia )) = 0, from (33), we define ∂eic ∂ Ŵic = ∇σ i (x iaj ) ẋiaj (t) = θ i , where θ i ∈ R lic . Thus, from (35), one can obtain
div.formula: e ic = -δ i -W T ic θ i . (36
div.p: In order to find the update law of the weight vector Ŵic , the objective function E ic = 1 2 e 2 ic should be minimized. Based on the steepest descent algorithm, Ŵic is updated by
div.formula: Ẇic = - Γ ic1 θ i (1 + θ T i θ i ) 2 ( e ic -δicM -η ic sgn( W T ic θ i ) ) ,(37)
div.p: where Γ ic1 and η ic are positive design constants. The robustness term δicM which estimates the upper-bound of δ i is updated by
div.formula: δicM = Γ ic2 W T ic θ i (1 + θ T i θ i ) 2 , (38
div.p: where Γ ic2 is a positive constant. We can observe that (37) is derived by updating δ icM with (38). Thus, (37) and ( 38) are the so-called nested update laws. Then, the local critic NN weight error dynamics becomes
div.formula: Ẇic = -Γ ic1 θ i (1 + θ T i θ i ) 2 × ( δ i + δ icM -δicM + W T ic θ i + η ic sgn( WT ic θ i ) ) , (39
div.p: where δicM = δ icM -δicM , which is updated by
div.formula: δicM = -Γ ic2 W T ic θ i (1 + θ T i θ i ) 2 .
div.p: Hence, the event-triggered DTC ( 20) is derived by
div.formula: ûi (x iaj ) = - 1 2 R -1 i ĝT ia (x iaj )∇ Vi (x iaj ). (41
div.p: Theorem 2: Considering the subsystem dynamics of the MRR ( 6), the weight error vector dynamics of the local critic NN Wic can be guaranteed to be asymptotically stable with the nested update laws (37) and (38).
Proof: Choose the Lyapunov function candidate as
div.formula: L i2 = 1 2 W T ic Γ -1 ic1 Wic + 1 2 Γ -1 ic2 δ2 icM . (42
div.p: Substituting ( 39) and ( 40) into the time derivative of (42), we have
div.formula: Li2 = W T ic Γ -1 ic1 Ẇic + Γ -1 ic2 δicM δicM = - W T ic θ i (1 + θ T i θ i ) 2 ( δ i + δ icM + W T ic θ i + η ic sgn( WT ic θ i ) ) - W T ic θ i (1 + θ T i θ i ) 2 δicM + Γ -1 ic2 δicM δicM ≤ -(η ic -2δ icM ) ∥ W T ic θi∥ (1+θ T i θi) 2 - ∥ W T ic θi∥ 2 (1+θ T i θi) 2 .
div.p: (43) Therefore, Li2 < 0 as long as the design parameter η ic > 2δ icM . It indicates that the weight error dynamics Wic of the local critic NN is ensured to be asymptotically stable. This completes the proof.

div.head: D. Stability analysis
div.p: Definition 1: (Class-K function) For a continuous function α : [0, a) → [0, ∞), it is called a class-K function if α is strictly increasing and α(0) = 0.

Theorem 3: Considering the entire dynamics of MRR given by (1), the rewritten subsystem dynamics given by ( 6), the local critic NN whose weight vector is tuned by the nested update laws (37) and (38), and the Assumptions 1-4, the closedloop system of MRR can be guaranteed to be asymptotically stable with the event-triggered DTC given by (41) and the triggering condition as
div.formula: ∥e iaj ∥ 2 ≤ λ min (R i ) ∥û i (x iaj )∥ 2 + (1 -β 2 i )λ min (Q i ) ∥e i ∥ 2 2λ max (R i )k 2 i - 2 ( W 2 icM σ 2 icM + ε 2 icM ) k 2 i = ∥e iT ∥ , (44
div.p: where 0 < β i < 1 is a constant, and e iT ≥ 0 is the threshold. Proof: Choose the Lyapunov function candidate as
div.formula: L i3 = V * i (x ia ) + V * i (x iaj ) + 1 2 η2 i . (45
div.p: From ( 13), we can see that V * i (x ia ) > 0 for any x ia ̸ = 0 and V * i (0) = 0. It implies that V * i (x ia ) is a positive semidefinite function. Noticing that V * i (x iaj ) = 0 and taking the time derivative of (45), we have
div.formula: Li3 = V * i (x ia ) -ηi ηi . (46
div.p: According to the event-triggered mechanism, the stability analysis should be given in the following two cases.
Case 1: The events are not triggered, i.e., ∀t ∈ [t j , t j+1 ). (46) becomes
div.formula: Li3 = ∇V * i (x ia ) ẋia -ηi ηi = ∇V * i (x ia ) (f ia (x ia ) + g ia (x ia )û i (x iaj )) + ∇V * i (x ia )∆h ia (x a ) -ηi ηi = ∇V * i (x ia ) ( f ia (x ia ) + g ia (x ia )u * i (x ia ) ) -∇V * i (x ia )g ia (x ia ) (u * i (x ia ) -ûi (x iaj )) + ∇V * i (x ia )∆h ia (x a ) -ηi ηi . (47
div.p: Substituting ( 14) and ( 19) into (47), we have
div.formula: Li3 = V * i (x ia ) -ηi ηi = -ηi ∥∇V * i (x ia (t))∥ E i -x T ia (t)Q ia x ia (t) -u * T i (x ia )R i u * i (x ia ) + ∇V * i (x ia )∆h ia (x a ) -ηi ηi + 2u * T i (x ia )R i (u * i (x ia ) -ûi (x iaj )) = -ηi ∥∇V * i (x ia (t))∥ E i -x T ia (t)Q ia x ia (t) -ûT i (x iaj )R i ûi (x iaj ) + ∇V * i (x ia )∆h ia (x a ) -ηi ηi + ( u * T i (x ia ) -u * i (x iaj ) + u * i (x iaj ) -ûi (x iaj ) ) T R i ( u * T i (x ia ) -u * i (x iaj ) + u * i (x iaj ) -ûi (x iaj ) ) .(48)
div.p: Considering (8) and Assumption 3, we have
div.formula: L = n ∑ i=1 Li3 = n ∑ i=1 ( V * i (x ia ) -ηi ηi ) ≤ n ∑ i=1 ( -η i ηi -ηi ∥∇V * i (x ia (t))∥ E i -e T i (t)Q i e i (t) -ûT i (x iaj )R i ûi (x iaj ) + 2λ max (R i )k 2 i ∥e iaj ∥ 2 +2λ max (R i ) W T ic σ ic (x iaj ) + ε ic 2 -ηi ηi ) + n ∑ i=1 max ik {d ik } ∇V * T i (x ia ) n ∑ k=1,k̸ =i E k ≤ n ∑ i=1 ( -η i ηi -ηi ∥∇V * i (x ia (t))∥ E i -e T i (t)Q i e i (t) -ûT i (x iaj )R i ûi (x iaj ) + 2λ max (R i )k 2 i ∥e iaj ∥ 2 +2λ max (R i ) W T ic σ ic (x iaj ) + ε ic 2 -ηi ηi ) + n • max ik {d ik } n ∑ i=1 ∇V * T i (x ia ) E i . (49
div.p: Letting
div.formula: η i = n • max ik {d ik }, assuming Wic ≤ W icm , ∥σ ic (x iaj )∥ ≤ σ icM , ∥ε ic ∥ ≤ ε icM with W icm , σ icM , ε icM
div.p: all positive constants, and substituting (34) into (49), we have
div.formula: L ≤ n ∑ i=1 ( -λ min (Q i ) ∥e i ∥ 2 -λ min (R i ) ∥û i (x iaj )∥ 2 +2λ max (R i ) ( k 2 i e iaj 2 + 2W 2 icm σ 2 icM + 2ε 2 icM ) ) = n ∑ i=1 ( -λ min (Q i )β 2 i ∥e i ∥ 2 -λ min (Q i )(1 -β 2 i ) ∥e i ∥ + 2λ max (R i ) ( k 2 i ∥e iaj ∥ 2 + 2W 2 icm σ 2 icM + 2ε 2 icM ) -λ min (R i ) ∥û i (x iaj )∥ 2 ) . (50
div.p: Hence, (50
div.formula: ) implies that L ≤ n ∑ i=1 ( -λ min (Q i )β 2 i ∥e i ∥ 2 ) < 0
div.p: for any e i ̸ = 0 when the triggering condition (44) holds.
Case 2: The events are triggered, i.e., ∀t = t j+1 . The difference of the Lyapunov function candidate (45) is
div.formula: ∆L i3 = L i3 (x iaj (t j+1 )) -L i3 (x iaj (t - j+1 )) = ∆V * i (x ia (t)) + ∆V * i (x iaj (t)) + 1 2 ∆η 2 i (t),(51)
div.p: where
div.formula: x iaj (t - j+1 ) = lim ν→0 x iaj (t j+1 -ν).
div.p: Considering the fact that the subsystem state and local cost function are both continuous, we have
div.formula: ∆V * i (x iaj (t)) = V * i (x iaj (t j+1 )) -V * i (x iaj (t j )) ≤ -K ( e ia(j+1) (t j ) ) , (54
div.p: where K(•) is a class-K function and e ia(j+1
div.formula: ) (t j ) = x ia(j+1) - x iaj . Therefore, ∆L i3 ≤ -K ( e ia(j+1) (t j ) ) , which implies that the entire Lyapunov function candidate L = n ∑ i=1 L i3 is
div.p: decreasing at all triggering instants t = t j+1 .

From the proof of these two cases, the closed-loop system of entire MRR is guaranteed to be asymptotically stable by employing the event-triggered DTC scheme (41) and the triggering condition (44). This completes the proof.

Remark 3: Since the design parameters R i , Q i , β i , k i , and the variables ûi and e i are selected or determined for subsystem i, thus (44) is indeed an event-triggered condition for the developed DTC (20) of the subsystem i.

div.head: E. Zeno behavior exclusion
div.p: Definition 2: (Zeno behavior) The nonlinear system is Zeno

where ∆t j = t j+1 -t j is defined as the jth intersampling time, and t ∞ is called the Zeno time [37]. Remark 4: For the event-triggered DTC input of the ith subsystem of MRR, defining the minimal intersampling time as ∆t min = min j∈N {t j+1 -t j }, which might be zero, it thus may result in the occurrence of the Zeno behavior. In this part, we will proof that the unexpected Zeno behavior can be avoided.
Assumption 5: The nonlinear function
div.formula: f ia (x ia ) is uniformly bounded on Ω i , i.e., sup xia∈Ωi ∥f ia (x ia )∥ ≤ b if ∥x ia ∥, where b if is a positive constant.
div.p: Theorem 4: Considering the closed form of MRR subsystem (6) and the developed event-triggered DTC scheme (41), the minimal intersampling time ∆t min has lower bound as
div.formula: ∆t min ≥ 1 b if ln ( ∥e iaj ∥ λ i + 1 ) > 0, i = 1, 2, . . . , n, (56
div.p: where λ i is positive constant. Proof: The event-triggered error dynamics is derived as
div.formula: ėiaj = ẋia -ẋiaj ≡ ẋia , ∀t ∈ [t j , t j+1 ), j ∈ N.(57)
div.p: By employing the DTC (41) and Assumption 5, the closed form of MRR subsystem dynamics can be expressed as
div.formula: ∥ ėiaj ∥ = ∥ ẋia ∥ ≤ b if ∥e iaj ∥ + b if ∥x iaj ∥ + 1 2 g ia (x ia )R -1 i g ia (x iaj )∇σ ic (x iaj ) Ŵic ≤ b if ∥e iaj ∥ + b if ∥x iaj ∥ + κ i , (58
div.p: where
div.formula: κ i = 1 2 λ max (R -1 i )g 2 iaM σ
div.p: icm W icM by assuming ∥∇σ ic (x iaj )∥ ≤ σ icm and Ŵic ≤ W icM with σ icm and W icM all positive constants.
By solving (58), we can obtain
div.formula: ∥e iaj ∥ ≤ b if ∥x iaj ∥ + κ i b if ( e b if (t-tj ) -1 )(59)
div.p: for any t ∈ [t j , t j+1 ).
Letting
div.formula: λ i = b if ∥xiaj ∥+κi b if
div.p: , the jth intersampling time satisfies
div.formula: t j+1 -t j ≥ 1 b if ln ( ∥e iaj ∥ λ i + 1 ) > 0.(60)
div.p: That is to say, ∆t min = min{t j+1 -t j } > 0, the formula (56) is true. This completes the proof. Remark 5: The controllable of the subsystem ( 6) is essentially a fundamental condition for control problem. It is a common assumption that the dynamics of real implementations (MRR is included as a special kind of robot) is continuous and Lipschitz [38], [39], which leads to the Lipschitz condition in Assumption 3 and boundedness property in Assumption 5. The desired trajectory to be tracked is feasible to assume to be bounded as an available positive constant since it is given by users in practice. In Assumption 4, δ i is the predefined approximation error related to Hamiltonian of the MRR subsystem, thus it can be assumed to be bounded with a positive constant. Overall, all the assumptions for developing the event-triggered DTC scheme are reasonable.

div.head: IV. SIMULATION STUDY
div.p: To test the effectiveness of the developed event-triggered DTC scheme, the Configuration B in [14] is taken as an example for simulation. The desired trajectories of two joint modules are defined as
div.formula: q d = [ q 1d q 2d ] = [ 0.2 sin(3t) + 0.1 cos (4t) 0.3 sin(2t) + 0.2 cos(t)
div.p: The initial values of subsystems and decentralized NN observers, and the related control parameters are listed in Table I.

For each joint module, we establish a local critic NN with 4-10-1 structure, i.e., 4 input neurons, 10 hidden neurons and 1 output neuron, to approximate the local optimal cost function (13) via "trial and error" for several times until the approximation error satisfies a given ] , and the weight vector is chosen as Ŵic = [ Ŵic1 , Ŵic2 , . . . , Ŵic10 ] T .

The simulation results are depicted in Figs. 23456. Fig. 2 illustrates the observation errors of the decentralized NN observer converge to a small region of the equilibrium point. The derived local input gain matrix is used to develop the DTC for each joint of MRR. Fig. 3 illustrates the trajectory tracking performance by using the developed event-triggered DTC (41). We can see that the actual trajectories can follow their desired ones within 4 sec. The input curves of the event-triggered DTC are displayed in Fig. 4. The magnified curves in these two figures show that the subsystem states are updated only when the events are triggered. The gap function (17) between the time-triggered and event-triggered subsystem states are shown as Fig. 5, and the entire subsystem error is sufficiently small for proper industrial requirements. In Fig. 6, the x-axis shows the time-triggered iteration sequence, the blue " * " and red " " denote the event-triggered iteration sequences for joint modules 1 and 2, respectively. The iteration sequences of communication for the time-triggered and eventtriggered DTC with different operation time-scales are listed in Table II. In contrast to the time-triggered DTC scheme, the computation, communication and energy cost are all reduced in the event-triggered DTC, which are significant in many real applications.

Remark 6: In the event-triggered control methods, the sampling time-instants for updating the DTC policy (20) of each joint module are determined by a certain triggering condition (44), rather than fixed time-interval in the time-scheduled control methods. Thus, the time of information exchange is always reduced, and the control action is computed and updated only when the sensor information is exchanged. It implies that the computational burden will be reduced. From scheduled control methods exchange the related information at each sampling time-instant. However, actuators receives the event-triggered control input which is computed and updated only when the triggering condition is held at some of the time instants in time-scheduled control. It reduces the information exchange among controllers and actuators, as well as the time of computation. Thus, the computation efficiency is improved. Besides, the triggering condition is designed as (44) which depends on the users to guarantee the closed-loop system of MRR asymptotically stable. It varies along with the interacting factors, i.e., control action ûi (x iaj ), the tracking error e i and the local critic NN parameters. That is to say, the parameter β i and k i should be set properly. The threshold e iT is smaller when β i or k i is larger, or both of them are larger, and vice versa. To tradeoff them, the users should set these two parameters according to the requirement of the control performance.

Remark 7: Theorem 4 and its proof illustrate that the minimal intersampling time ∆t min > 0, which ensures that the unexpected Zeno behavior can be avoided. The actual value of ∆t min is not necessary to know in the example, since it cannot influence the control performance and results.

Remark 8: On one hand, the decentralized NN observer for each isolated joint module is established by using the local input-output data and desired states of the coupling joint modules, the local critic NN is constructed by using the local state as well. Following that, the event-triggered DTC can be derived by local joint module states only. On the other hand, simulation results of the 2-DOF MRR show that the actual trajectory of joint module 1 follows its desired one without affecting the control performance of joint module 2, and vice versa. From the theoretical analysis and simulation results, we can see that the proposed event-triggered DTC is reasonable and effective to modularized MRRs regardless how many joint modules they have, and the information exchange is greatly saved.

Remark 9: In engineering practice, the control accuracy of the MRR system is affected by many issues, such as the vibration caused by the flexibility of the moving MRR, the mechanical accuracy, external disturbances and joint frictions. However, it should be noticed that the main focus of this work is to develop an ADP-based event-triggered DTC method for MRRs, and simulation results can draw the conclusion sufficiently as expected from obtained theory results. In other words, experimental verification based on the new prepared 2-DOF MRR platform (shown in Fig. 1) with consideration of above mentioned issues, which is an adequate and challenge work with the complex and heavy task in our future research, will be provided to better reveal the effectiveness of the developed DTC approach.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, the ADP-based DTC scheme is developed for MRRs by using event-triggered mechanism. Based on local input-output data and desired states of coupled subsystems, the decentralized NN observer is established to identify the local input gain matrix, which is utilized to design the DTC. The interconnection is inserted to construct the modified local cost function, and the local HJB equation is solved by a local critic NN with nested updating weight vector. The simulation results show that the developed DTC ensures the actual trajectory of each joint of MRR follow its desired one successfully, and the computation, communication and energy cost are all reduced since the event-triggered mechanism is introduced in the controller design. The main focus of this paper is on developing the event-triggered DTC scheme based on ADP for MRRs, whose effectiveness is demonstrated by simulation results of a numerical 2-DOF MRR system. In our future work, experimental verification of MRRs with different DOF (shown in Fig. 1), which is significant to test its effectiveness and correctness, will be considered.

div.p: , IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON INDUSTRIAL ELECTRONICS Bo Zhao (M'16) received his B.S. degree in Automation, and Ph.D. degree in Control Science and Engineering, all from Jilin University, Changchun, China, in 2009 and 2014, respectively. He was a Post-Doctoral Fellow with the State Key Laboratory of Management and Control for Complex Systems, Institute of Automation, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China, from 2014 to 2017. Then, he joined the State Key Laboratory of Management and Control for Complex Systems, Institute of Automation, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China, from 2017 to 2018. He is currently an Associate Professor with the School of Systems Science, Beijing Normal University, Beijing, China. His research interests include adaptive dynamic programming, robot control, fault diagnosis and tolerant control, optimal control, and neural-network based control. Derong Liu (S'91-M'94-SM'96-F'05) received the Ph.D. degree in electrical engineering from the University of Notre Dame, Notre Dame, IN, USA, in 1994. He was a Staff Fellow with General Motors Research and Development Center, Warren, MI, USA, from 1993 to 1995. He was an Assistant Professor with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Stevens Institute of Technology, Hoboken, NJ, USA, from 1995 to 1999. He joined the University of Illinois at Chicago, Chicago, IL, USA, in 1999, and became a Full Professor of He has authored or co-authored over 18 books. Prof. Liu was a recipient of the Michael J. Birck Fellowship from the University of Notre Dame, in 1990, the Harvey N. Davis Distinguished Teaching Award from the Stevens Institute of Technology, in 1997, the Faculty Early Career Development Award from the National Science Foundation in 1999, the University Scholar Award from the University of Illinois, from 2006 to 2009, and the Overseas Outstanding Young Scholar Award from the National Natural Science Foundation of China in 2008. He was selected for the "100 Talents Program" by the Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2008. He was the Editor-in-Chief of the IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems from 2010 to 2015. He is the Editor-in-Chief of Artificial Intelligence Review (Springer). He is a fellow of the International Neural Network Society and the International Association of Pattern Recognition.
